ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about Mexican-American border history and a lot of queer theory. I learned how to write an academic research paper well.

I developed a framework to understand border politics, history, and migration. This class allowed us to explore our academic interests in a safe, engaging space. For instance, we learned how to view and address historical events and themes from a critical, academic perspective. The culminating projects for this class were thought-provoking and so original. My classmates were all wonderful scholars, and I look forward to seeing what they publish in the future.
I learned about the history of the North American Southwest through the lenses of race and sexuality.

I learned a lot about borderlands history, definitely, But I think the most valuable learning from this class were the skills. This course had as its goal for its students to understand borderlands, race, and sexuality as analytics/frameworks when writing (or reading). I think it definitely achieved that goal for me. I came into the course not having this skill, of viewing texts or sources from certain frameworks, but I can now say 100% I gained it. I am now able to read texts and sources using these lenses. I think this course also taught me a lot about the process of writing scholarship. We talked about the context in which scholars wrote, how that influenced their work, and the implications of the analyses they presented. Also, our entire course was also based around epistemology and critically thinking about the writing of history, like no other course I've taken did before. I really learned a ton in this class.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Really talented prof, amazing lecture/seminar ratio, really intimate course setting
Weaknesses: nothing

Professor Hernndez does a fantastic job of giving a presentation, connecting the lesson to the readings, and segueing into a group discussion. Even though the class was very small, we were all engaged excited to discuss the readings. I really loved how close-knit the class became. Even though it was virtual, we all formed a community in this space.

In terms of improvement, I would've loved to engage with different borderlands and the histories of other communities in addition to the American Southwest. Also, I wish the course had been once-a-week longer seminar instead of a twice-weekly shorter seminar.
I liked the breakout sessions and the class activities.

Strengths: Foundational knowledge building - the professor really made sure that before going deep into each reading, that we all understood some base/foundational terms and context so that we all started at the same place; the professor - professor Hernandez is AMAZING, incredibly kind, and incredibly supportive; the readings - I learned a TON from these readings, and I'll definitely be using them in the future; the community - even though this class was of course via zoom, I truly honestly made friends out of this class; the skills I gained from this course I can say as a humanities major that I will use for the rest of my undergrad and probably beyond

Weaknesses: some days were a bit less engaging than others; I would remove or adjust the role playing activities...

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Given the small size of the class, discussion flowed really well, and we were able to engage with each other thoughtfully. However, sometimes breakout rooms were unnecessary because the class was so small.
Professor Hernandez was super flexible and willing to go the extra mile to support us as students.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: 100 percent. This was my favorite course of all time at Yale. The readings are riveting and I learned so much without having to stress that my commentary would be viewed as less intellectually nuanced than anyone else.
Absolutely! Professor Hernndez is great, and it's such an interesting course.
Yes! This course challenged a lot of the histories I learned growing up and is super relevant and important to understanding the region today
Yes! If you're interested in borderlands history definitely.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
